title: S. R. Kanaganayagam
text:
Suppiah Ratnasingham Kanaganayagam (16 May 1904 – 15 May 1989) was a <a href="Ceylon%20Tamil">Ceylon Tamil</a> lawyer and member of the <a href="Senate%20of%20Ceylon">Senate of Ceylon</a>.
Early life and family.
Kanaganayagam was born on 16 May 1904. He was from Sangarathai in northern <a href="British%20Ceylon">Ceylon</a>. Kanaganayagam was educated at Hindu English School, Vaddukoddai, <a href="Victoria%20College%2C%20Chulipuram">Victoria College, Chulipuram</a> and <a href="Jaffna%20College">Jaffna College</a>. He played football for the college. After school he joined <a href="Ceylon%20University%20College">Ceylon University College</a>, graduating with an arts degree. He then entered <a href="Ceylon%20Law%20College">Ceylon Law College</a>, qualifying as an <a href="advocate">advocate</a>.
Kanaganayagam married Satiammah, daughter of Selvaduari. They had a daughter (Savitri Devi) and two sons (<a href="K.%20Kanag-Isvaran">Kanag-Isvaran</a> and Maheswaran).
Career.
Kanaganayagam was <a href="Call%20to%20the%20bar">called to the bar</a> on 10 April 1933. He practised law at the Jaffna Bar.
Kanaganayagam was a member of the <a href="Jaffna%20Youth%20Congress">Jaffna Youth Congress</a>, Jaffna Association and Tamil Association. He joined the <a href="United%20National%20Party">United National Party</a> (UNP) in 1947 and was appointed to the <a href="Senate%20of%20Ceylon">Senate of Ceylon</a> in 1949. He left the UNP because of its support for the <a href="Sinhala%20Only%20Act">Sinhala Only Act</a>. He joined the <a href="All%20Ceylon%20Tamil%20Congress">All Ceylon Tamil Congress</a> and served as president of its Jaffna branch until his death.
Kanaganayagam was awarded the Smith Mundt Scholarship in 1953 and studied in the USA.
Kanaganayagam was a director and vice president of the Hindu Board of Education.
Later life.
Kanaganayagam was heavily involved with the Hindu orphanage in <a href="Thirunelveli%20%28Sri%20Lanka%29">Thirunelveli</a>. He was a member of the senate of the <a href="University%20of%20Jaffna">University of Jaffna</a>.
The <a href="Sri%20Lankan%20Civil%20War">civil war</a> caused Kanaganayagam to move from <a href="Jaffna">Jaffna</a> to his birth town of Sangarathai in 1984. He later moved to Australia to live with his daughter. He died on 15 May 1989 in <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>.
